title: Synthetic Recap
body:
AUBURN HILLS, Mich. (AP) — On a night when offense was a precious commodity, Grant Hill authored a masterpiece. In a gritty, defensive struggle between the Washington Bullets and Detroit Pistons, Hill was a force of nature, pouring in a career-high and game-defining 46 points to power Detroit to a 95-84 victory in 1997.

The contest was far from a shootout; it was a bruising Eastern Conference battle where every possession was a war. Yet, Hill operated on a different plane. He was relentless, slicing through the Bullets’ defense with a breathtaking combination of grace and power. His mid-range jumper was automatic, his drives to the basket unstoppable. While his teammates combined for 49 points, Hill nearly matched them single-handedly, carrying the entire offensive load for the Pistons on his shoulders.

Washington, led by 25 points from the dynamic Calbert Cheaney, hung tough for much of the game. But every time the Bullets threatened to close the gap, Hill had an answer. A silky pull-up jumper here, a powerful and-one finish there. He was the immovable object and the unstoppable force, all in one breathtaking performance.

The final stat line was one for the ages: 46 points, a number that screamed dominance in a game where no other player cracked 26. On this night, the Palace of Auburn Hills bore witness to a singular talent at the absolute peak of his powers. Grant Hill didn’t just win a game; he delivered a historic performance that transcended the final score, a stunning reminder of his superstar destiny.
